title-group.article-title: Modeling underplatform dampers for turbine blades: a refined approach in the frequency domain

author-notes.corresp: Stefano Zucca, Politecnico di Torino, Mechanical Engineering Department, Corso Duca degli Abruzzi 24, Torino 10129, Italy Email: stefano.zucca@polito.it

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Friction damping is one of the most exploited systems of passive control of the vibration of mechanical systems. In order to mitigate vibration of turbine blades, friction dampers are commonly included in the bladed disk design. A common type of blade-to-blade friction dampers are the so-called underplatform dampers (UPDs); these are metal devices placed under the blade platforms and held in contact with them by the centrifugal force acting during rotation. The effectiveness of UPDs to dissipate energy by friction and reduce vibration amplitude depends mostly on the damper geometry and material and on the static loads pressing the damper against the blade platforms. The common procedure used to estimate the static loads acting on UPDs consists in decoupling the static and the dynamic balance of the damper. A preliminary static analysis of the contact is performed in order to compute the static pressure distribution over the damper/blade interfaces, assuming that it does not change when vibration occurs. In this paper a coupled approach is proposed. The static and the dynamic displacements of blade and UPD are coupled together during the forced response calculation. Both the primary structure (the bladed disk) and the secondary structure (the damper) are modeled by finite elements and linked together by contact elements, allowing for stick, slip and lift off states, placed between each pair of contact nodes, by using a refined version of the state-of-the-art friction contact model. In order to model accurately the blade/damper contact with a large number of contact nodes without increasing proportionally the size of the set of nonlinear equations to be solved, damper and blade dynamics are modeled by linear superposition of a truncated series of normal modes. The proposed method is applied to a bladed disk under cyclic symmetric boundary conditions in order to show the capabilities of the method compared to the classical decoupled approaches.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: The large vibration amplitude of turbine blades due to resonance conditions occurring in service may lead to unacceptable blade failure for high cycle fatigue (HCF). Since blade detuning is not always possible in bladed disks, the response level must be reduced increasing the damping of the system.

In order to control passively the blade response level, friction dampers are designed in order to dissipate energy during blade vibration. A common damper configuration is the so-called underplatform damper (UPD). A metal device placed under the blade platforms and pressed against them by the centrifugal force due to the shaft rotation. A common UPD configuration is the wedge shaped damper, with the inclined surfaces in contact with the blade platforms.

Over the last ten years, UPDs have been largely studied in order to develop and validate models able to describe the damper behavior during blade vibration and suitable to be included in nonlinear solvers developed to compute the forced response of frictionally damped bladed disks in the frequency domain and based on the harmonic balance method (HBM).

According to HBM (Cardona et al., 1998), the periodical response of the system and the periodical contact forces are expressed as a superposition of harmonic terms, and the differential balance equations of the system are turned into a set of algebraic nonlinear equations with complex coefficients.

In the pioneering works Yang and Menq (1998a,b) and Sanliturk et al. (2001) damper kinematics is deduced assuming full contact between the damper and the blades. In Panning et al. (2003, 2004), Petrov and Ewins (2007) and Zucca et al. (2008) dampers are modeled as rigid bodies able to rotate and partially detach from the blade platforms during vibration.

Damper and blade platforms are coupled together by means of contact elements (Yang and Menq, 1998c; Yang et al., 1998; Petrov and Ewins, 2003; Cigeroglu et al., 2007), where contact stiffness is simulated by means of spring elements, able to model the different states occurring at the contact during vibration: stick, slip, lift-off.

Furthermore in Firrone et al. (2006), Petrov (2007), Szwedowicz et al. (2008) and Cigeroglu et al. (2009), UPDs are also modeled with the finite element method (FEM) in order to take into account also the bulk elasticity of the damper and not only the contact stiffness at the blade/damper interfaces.

One of the key factors for the efficiency of UPDs is the static normal load acting on the contact surfaces, depending on the centrifugal force of the damper and therefore on the damper mass. A too large mass may prevent the damper slipping and dissipating energy, while a too small mass may induce the damper to lift-off from the blade platforms.

In all the models available in the literature, a two-step procedure is used to compute the effect of UPDs on bladed disk dynamics:
the static normal loads acting at the damper/blade contact surfaces are computed by means of a static analysis assuming that no blade vibration is occurring.
the dynamic balance of the frictionally damped system is computed by HBM, using the static normal loads computed at step 1.
In this way static and dynamic balance equations of the system are uncoupled and it is assumed that the static normal loads are not affected by the blade and damper vibration.

In this paper, a method is proposed to solve by HBM the coupled set of static and dynamic balance equations of a bladed disk with UPDs. Static loads acting at the damper/blade contact surfaces are directly related to static relative displacements between the bodies in contact.

A first simplified version of this method, limited to UPD characterized by a rigid body kinematics, has been presented in Firrone et al. (2009). Here the method is extended to the more general case where UPDs are modeled by FEM and no hypotheses are made about the UPD kinematics.

The key point of the proposed method is the refinement of the state-of-the-art contact model available in the literature (Yang et al., 1998) to compute the forced response of bladed disks with UPDs. The refined contact model allows coupling of the static and the dynamic balance equations of the system without any need of preliminary calculations and related assumptions.
As a result, the static and the dynamic balance equations of the system are coupled and no preliminary static calculation is necessary to estimate the static load distribution over the contact area.

sec.title: 2. Bladed disk with underplatform dampers
sec.p:
Bladed disks are bodies made of a number NS of nominally identical sectors equally spaced over a 2π angle, as shown in Figure 1. Bladed disks rotate with angular speed Ω in a non-uniform pressure field, so that from a relative reference system fixed to the bladed disk, it is excited by an external periodical excitation rotating in the opposite direction. The spatial periodicity of the excitation depends on the number of vane segments of the stator stages preceding and following the bladed disk. Figure 1.
Dummy bladed disk for vibration analysis; left (L) and right (R) contact areas of a wedge damper and damper angles αL and αR.

By means of Fourier analysis, the vector of periodical rotating forces, known as traveling wave excitation, can be split in different vectors of harmonic rotating forces: (1)F(t)=F(0)+ℜ(F(n)·einΩt)with n=1..∞
The harmonic index n of the harmonic components is called engine order.

At a given speed, multiple engine orders excite the bladed disk. When the frequency of one of the engine orders coincide with one of the natural frequencies of the bladed disk, and a proper relationship holds between the engine order and the number of nodal diameters of the related mode shape (Petrov, 2004), high response levels of the blades may occur.
In order to reduce the vibration amplitude, UPDs are placed under the blade platforms to dissipate energy by friction at the blade/damper contact surfaces.

A common configuration of UPDs, the object of this study, are the so-called wedge dampers, shown in Figure 1, whose contact areas with the blade platforms correspond to the inclined surfaces (L and R in Figure 1) of the damper, inclined of angles αL and αR with respect to the y-axis shown in Figure 1.

In the calculation of the forced response of bladed disks with UPDs, the bladed disk represents the primary structure and the UPDs are the secondary unconstrained structures, whose motion is constrained by the blade platforms during service.

sec.title: 2.1. Bladed disk model
sec.p: Consider a bladed disk excited by an engine-order-type excitation of angular frequency ω; in order to compute the forced response of bladed disks with UPDs, a finite element model of the bladed disk must be developed.

The nonlinear differential balance equation of the bladed disk are (2)M·Q··(t)+C·Q·(t)+K·Q(t)=Feo(t)-FD(t), with M, C and K the mass, damping and stiffness matrices and Q the vector nodal degrees-of-freedom (d.f.) of the bladed disk, Feo an engine-order-type harmonic excitation characterized by an excitation angular frequency ω = n*Ω, with n* a given engine order, and FD the nonlinear contact forces exerted by the blade platforms to the UPDs.

If the periodical displacements and contact forces are approximated with a Fourier series truncated at the first order (3)Q(t)=Q(0)+ℜ(Q(1)·ei·ω·t)FD(t)=FD(0)+ℜ(FD(1)·ei·ω·t), by applying the HBM, the nonlinear second-order differential equations (2) become nonlinear algebraic equations with complex coefficients (4)K·Q(0)=-FD(0)D(ω)·Q(1)=Feo-FD(1), where D(ω)=K+iωC-ω2M is the dynamic stiffness matrix.
The first equation of (4) represents the static balance of the bladed disk, the second equation of (4) represents the first term of the dynamic balance of the bladed disk.

sec.title: 2.2. Damper model
sec.p: The UPD is modeled by means of 3D solid finite elements, in order to avoid any assumption about either the damper kinematics or the influence of UPD bulk stiffness on the damper dynamics.

In order to have a UPD model consistent with the bladed disk model, for each contact node placed over the contact surfaces of the blade platforms, a corresponding contact node is located over the contact surfaces of the damper (Figure 2). Figure 2.
Damper and blade finite element method.

In order to simulate properly local phenomena such as partial stick, microslip or lift-off due to the complex UPD kinematics, all the nodes lying on the damper surface (and on the blade platform) are selected as contact nodes (around 100 over each UPD side, as shown in Figure 2).

The differential balance equations of the UPD are (5)MD·Q··D(t)+CD·Q·D(t)+KD·QD(t)=FC+FD(t), with MD, CD and KD the mass, damping and stiffness matrices and QD the vector of damper d.f., FC the centrifugal force acting on the UPD and FD the contact forces exerted by the blade platforms to the UPDs.

Similarly of what has been done for the bladed disk, by HBM (6)QD(t)=QD(0)+ℜ(QD(1)·ei·ω·t)FD(t)=FD(0)+ℜ(FD(1)·ei·ω·t), and the nonlinear second-order differential equations (5) become a set of nonlinear algebraic equations with complex coefficients (7)KD·QD(0)=FC+FD(0)DD(ω)·QD(1)=FD(1), where DD(ω)=KD+iωCD-ω2MD is the UPD dynamic stiffness matrix.

In order to compute the forced response of the bladed disk with UPDs by means of equations (4) and (7), a contact element is necessary in order to compute the periodical contact forces FD and the corresponding 0th and 1st order harmonic terms.

sec.title: 3. Contact elements
sec.p:
In the technical literature, several authors have addressed the problem of modeling periodical contact forces at friction contacts due to periodical relative displacements of contact points for the subsequent implementation in numerical codes based on the harmonic balance method. As a result, four main contact elements have been developed:
1D tangential relative displacement and constant normal load (Griffin, 1980),
1D tangential relative displacement and variable normal load (Yang et al., 1998; Petrov and Ewins, 2003; Cigeroglu et al., 2007),
2D tangential relative displacement and constant normal load (Griffin and Menq, 1981; Sanliturk and Ewins, 1996; Menq and Yang, 1998),
2D tangential displacement and variable normal load (Yang and Menq, 1998c).

Contact models A and C are not suitable to model the contact forces occurring at the blade/damper interface, since they neglect the variation of normal loads during the system vibration and therefore partial separation of the contact surfaces cannot be modeled. On the contrary, since the contact models B and D allow partial separation to be taken into account, they have been extensively applied (Panning et al., 2003; Panning et al., 2004; Firrone et al., 2006; Petrov, 2007; Petrov and Ewins, 2007; Zucca et al., 2008; Cigeroglu et al., 2009) to model blade/UPD interfaces. Despite being the more advanced model available in the literature, contact model D is rarely used in industrial applications due to the large computational costs, recognized by one of the authors himself in Cigeroglu et al. (2009). As a consequence, contact model B based on 1D tangential relative displacements of the bodies in contact currently represents the state-of-the-art not only for UPDs but also in the case of shrouded blades (Siewert et al., 2009).

In the case of a 2D tangential kinematics of the bodies in contact, two perpendicular 1D contact models B are used to couple the bodies at each contact pair, and it is assumed that the corresponding two perpendicular slip directions are uncoupled to each other. In this way, a 2D tangential coupling is obtained by means of 1D contact elements (Petrov and Ewins, 2007; Cigeroglu et al., 2009; Siewert et al., 2009). On the basis of the above described considerations, contact model B has also been used in this study to connect each pair of UPD and blade contact nodes. The contact element, as shown in Figure 3, is made of two springs of stiffness kn and kt, simulating the normal and the tangential contact stiffness and connecting the Coulomb slider to one of the bodies in contact. Periodic normal and tangential contact forces can be computed from the periodic relative motion u(t) in the tangential direction and v(t) in the normal direction. Figure 3.
Contact element.

Three states are possible:
– stick: the tangential force T is lower than the Coulomb limit force μN, being μ the coefficient of friction and N the normal force,
– slip: the tangential force T reaches the Coulomb limit force μN,
– lift-off: the contact forces are null.

During a cycle, transitions between the three states are possible; a full description of all the possible transitions for this contact element, beyond the scope of this paper, is given in Petrov and Ewins (2003), Panning et al. (2004). For a small displacement amplitude, the contact is fully stuck, as the tangential relative displacement becomes larger, the contact may enter the slip state during a part of the period, while increasing the normal relative displacement partial lift-off of the contact may occur.

The original equations of contact forces during the possible states are shown below. The normal load is defined as (8)N(t)=max[N0+kn·v~(t),0], where the term N0 represents the static normal load, acting over the contact due to the presence of the centrifugal force without vibration, and v~(t) the harmonic normal relative displacement, perturbing the static contact conditions.
The tangential contact force depends on the contact state: (9)T(t)={Kt·(u(t)-w(t)) in stick state sgn(w·(t))·μ·N(t) in slip state 0 in lift-off state

In the literature, when this contact element is used to model the contact forces generated at the blade/UPD interfaces, the calculation of normal pre-loads N0 acting at each contact pair is performed offline, i.e. before the solution of the nonlinear static and dynamic balance equations of the full system (bladed disk + UPD) described in Section 2.

Different approaches are used; for instance, in Panning et al. (2004) and Petrov and Ewins (2007) rigid body balance equations are implemented together with a simplified hypothesis about the tangential and normal load distribution over the contact area. In Cigeroglu et al. (2009) a quasi-static nonlinear analysis is used and in Szwedowicz et al. (2008) nonlinear static analysis is performed by FEM. In all these approaches a preliminary static solution is performed in order to compute the static normal loads acting on the contact and subsequently it is assumed that system vibration does not affect the distribution of normal pre-loads, from which periodical tangential contact forces depend.

In order to avoid a preliminary static analysis and to couple the static and the dynamic balance equations of the system (bladed disk + UPD) in the numerical solver a set of refinements is necessary for the above described constitutive equations of the contact model. In detail, refinements that involve both the static component of the normal force N and the static component of the tangential force T, are introduced.

At this point, it is relevant mentioning that, since absolute displacements of contact points are expressed in equations (3) and (10) as linear superposition of the 0th and 1st order harmonic terms, also the relative displacements for the generic contact element are (10)u(t)=u(0)+ℜ(u(1)·ei·ω·t)v(t)=v(0)+ℜ(v(1)·ei·ω·t).

The term v(0) represents the static relative normal displacement between the bodies in contact at the generic contact point. If v(0) ≥ 0 the two bodies are in contact, while if v(0) < 0 there is an initial gap between the two bodies. As a consequence, the static component of the contact normal load, necessary to compute the periodic tangential load, is directly linked to the static component v(0) of the normal relative displacement of the bodies in contact. Since kn is the normal contact stiffness, the constitutive equation of the contact normal load can be written as (11)N(t)=max[kn·v(t),0]=max[kn·v(0)+kn·ℜ(v(1)·ei·ω·t),0].

Replacing equation (8) with equation (11) in the set of constitutive equations of the contact, the periodic tangential contact forces can still be computed analytically as described in Yang et al. (1998).

The second refinement refers to the tangential contact force in case of a full-stick state of the contact. As demonstrated in Yang et al. (1998) and Petrov and Ewins (2003), the periodic cycle of the tangential contact force T computed by means of the constitutive equations (9) is unique, if during the period the contact enters the slip state or the lift-off state. On the contrary if the vibration amplitude is not large enough to induce slip or lift-off and the contact is fully stuck, unique periodic tangential force T cannot be computed.

For instance, consider the case shown in Figure 4, where the thick lines represent the Coulomb limit curves ±μN and the thin lines represent two of the possible tangential forces T. Since u(t) is not large enough to enter the slip state, an infinite number of curves of the force T exists; the variable component of T(t), due to the variable component of u(t) is the same for all the curves, but the static component of T(t) is not unique and included in the range Tmin(0)≤T(0)≤Tmax(0), being Tmin(0) the value corresponding to the curve tangent to the lower Coulomb limit -μN and Tmax(0) the value corresponding to the curve tangent to the upper Coulomb limit +μN. Figure 4.
Full-stick state: variability on T(0) in case of variable N(t).

If the static balance equations (i.e. the 0th harmonic order of equation (6) and (13)) are not included in the set of balance equations to be solved, the issue that, using the contact element described in this paper, non-unique static components of the tangential contact force may occur in the case of full-stick contact conditions is negligible. On the contrary it becomes relevant when the static balance is coupled with the dynamic balance because non-unique values of static contact forces lead to a range of variability in the forced response of the system (Zucca et al., 2008).

In order to have unique values of tangential contact force T(t), in case of full-stick state of the contact, the following refinement of the contact model is here proposed, based on a predictor-corrector approach.
In case of full-stick state, the tangential force is initially set equal to (12)T(t)=kt·u(0)+kt·ℜ(u(1)·eiωt).

If (13)Tmin(0)≤kt·u(0)≤Tmax(0), then no correction is made. From the physical point of view, this is the case when the static tangential displacement u(0) is not high enough to have slip neither during the loading part nor during the unloading part of the hysteresis cycle.

On the contrary, if during the period it is verified that (14)kt·u(0)>Tmax(0), the value of equation (12) is corrected as (15)T(t)=Tmax(0)+kt·ℜ(u(1)·eiωt), being Tmax0 the maximum static value of the tangential contact force corresponding to the curve tangent to the upper Coulomb limit +μN. From the physical point of view, this is the case when the static tangential displacement u(0) is high enough to induce positive slip (T = μN) during the first loading cycle, but then the stabilized hysteresis cycle is perfectly elastic with maximum tangential force equal to the upper Coulomb limit value μN.

At the same way, if (16)kt·u(0)<Tmin(0), the value of equation (12) is corrected as (17)T(t)=Tmin0+kt·ℜ(u(1)·eiωt), being Tmin0 the minimum static value of the tangential contact force corresponding to the curve tangent to the lower Coulomb limit −μN. From the physical point of view, this is the case when the static tangential displacement u(0) is low enough to induce negative slip (T = −μN) during the first unloading cycle, but then the stabilized hysteresis cycle is perfectly elastic with a minimum tangential force equal to the lower Coulomb limit value −μN.

Once the above described refinements are included in the constitutive equations of the contact element and used to compute the periodical contact forces and their 0th and 1st order Fourier terms, the Fourier components FD(0) and FD(1) of the contact forces can be defined in the static and dynamic balance equations (4) and (7). By means of the proposed modifications the coupled set of static and dynamic balance equations of the bladed disk and of the UPD allows computing a unique forced response without any preliminary static calculation of simplified hypothesis about the distribution of normal pre-loads over the damper sides.

sec.title: 4. Model reduction
sec.p: The solution of balance equations (4) and (7), coupled by means of the refined contact element described in Section 3, would allow computing the forced response of the bladed disk. Anyway, in industrial applications, the size of the model is so large that a reduction technique must be applied to the FE models of the bladed disk and of the damper in order to obtain acceptable calculation times. In case of bladed disks with UPDs, in Panning et al. (2003) and in Cigeroglu et al. (2009), the modal superposition approach can be successfully used to reduce the bladed disk; physical d.f. are expressed as a superposition of a subset of normal mode shapes (18)Q(0)=Φ·η(0)Q(1)=Φ·η(1), being Φ the subset of M-normalized eigenvectors, η(0) and η(1) the vectors of 0th and 1st Fourier terms of the modal amplitudes of the bladed disk.

The balance equations (4) in modal coordinates become (19)Λ0·η(0)=-fD(0)Λ1(ω)·η(1)=feo-fD(1), where Λ0 and Λ1 are diagonal matrices with (20)Λjj·=λjΛ1(ω)jj·=λj-ω2+i·2ωζjλj being λj the jth eigenvalue of the bladed disk and ζj the jth modal damping ratio and terms in the right hand-side of the equation are the modal forces obtained by projecting the physical forces over the basis formed by the mode shapes of the bladed disk (21)fD(0)=ΦT·FD(0)feo=ΦT·FeofD(1)=ΦT·FD(1).

The same approach is used also for the damper; a linear modal analysis of the damper is performed, computing both eigenvalues λD and M-normalized eigenvectors ΦD and expressing physical displacements by linear superposition of normal modes, including both rigid body mode shapes and elastic mode shapes (Cigeroglu et al., 2009) (22)QD(0)=ΦD·ηD(0)QD(1)=ΦD·ηD(1),

Then the balance equations (11) in modal coordinates become (23)ΛD0·ηD(0)=fC+fD(0)ΛD1(ω)·ηD(1)=fD(1), being ηD(0) and ηD(1) the vectors of 0th and 1st Fourier terms of the modal coefficients of the UPD and Λ0 and Λ1 diagonal matrices with (24)Λjj·=λDjΛD1(ω)jj·=λDj-ω2+i·2ωζDjλDj being λDj the jth eigenvalue of the damper, ζDj the jth modal damping ratio and (25)fD(0)=ΦDT·FD(0)fC=ΦDT·FCfD(1)=ΦDT·FD(1).
Since the damper is a free body, the first six eigenvalues have null values and therefore the first six rows of matrix ΛD0 have null coefficients, as shown in Cigeroglu et al. (2009).

In the case of a bladed disk with cyclic symmetry boundary conditions (Petrov, 2004), only the finite element model of the fundamental sector is necessary and equations (5) and (8), relating physical and modal d.f. of the bladed disk becomes (26)Q(0)=Φ(0)·η(0);fD(0)=Φ·FD(0)Q(1)=Φ(n*)·η(1);feo=Φ(n*)H·Feo;fD(1)=Φ·FD(1),
being Φ(0) the linear mode shapes of the bladed disk corresponding to a null inter-blade phase angle (IBPA) and Φ(n*) the mode shapes corresponding to IBPA = 2πn*/Ns.

The resulting balance equations of the bladed disk in modal coordinates, in this case, become (27)Λ0·η(0)=-fD(0)Λn*(ω)·η(1)=feo-fD(1), where Λ0 and Λn* are diagonal matrices with (28)Λjj·=λj(0)Λn*(ω)jj·=λj(n*)-ω2+i·2ωζj(n*)λj(n*) being λj and λjn* the jth eigenvalue of the bladed disk associated to the jth mode shape of Φ(0) and Φ(n*) respectively and ζj(n*) the jth modal damping ratio of the jth mode shape of Φ(n*).

sec.title: 5. Forced response calculation
sec.p: At the end of the reduction procedure, the new set of nonlinear balance equations in modal coordinates to be solved in the frequency domain includes equations (27) of the bladed disk and equations (23) of the damper.
Nonlinearity is introduced by the modal contact forces fD(0) and fD(1) depending from modal amplitudes η(0), η(1), ηD(0) and ηD(1).

An iterative solution scheme is necessary. The Newton-Raphson method, directly applied to equations (23) and (27) is not able to converge for any set of system parameters, in particular in the presence of turning points (also called limit points) of the frequency response function (FRF) curve, occurring in case of partial lift-off of the contact points, generating the so-called jump phenomenon (Yang et al., 1998; Cigeroglu et al., 2009).
To overcome this limitation, a predictor-corrector procedure based on the pseudo-arc length continuation method (Chan and Keller, 1982) is applied.

The first solution is computed with the classical Newton-Raphson approach applied to equations (23) and (27). Then, given the nth solution, the n + 1th solution is predicted by means of a tangent predictor, then the corrector step is implemented searching for the solution in a direction orthogonal to the predictor step. The augmented system of equations solved in the corrector step includes the balance equations (23) and (27) and the equation used to define the corrector step direction. As required by continuation methods, the vectors of the unknowns are also augmented, including the excitation frequency.

Within the above described numerical scheme, the following steps are performed:
The vector of the modal unknowns η(0), η(1), ηD(0) and ηD(1) is either guessed (for the first iteration) or computed during the previous iteration as well as the guess value of the angular frequency ω;
Absolute displacements Q(0), QD(0), Q(1) and QD(1) of contact nodes are computed by means of equations (22) and (26) and relative displacements u(0), v(0), u(1) and v(1) are then obtained.
Periodic contact forces T(t) and N(t) are computed with the refined contact model described in Section 3 for each contact element
0th and 1st Fourier terms of periodic contact forces T(t) and N(t) are computed and assembled in the vectors of physical contact forces FD(0) and FD(1).
Vectors of modal contact forces fD(0) and fD(1) are computed by means of equations (25) and (26).
Residuals of the set of nonlinear equations are computed.

If the residuals computed at step 6 are lower than the prescribed tolerance, the procedure ends. Otherwise, following the Newton-Raphson method, the Jacobian matrix of the system is computed, a new vector of the unknowns is computed and another iteration is performed.

sec.title: 6.1. Description
sec.p:
The methodology described in the previous sections is here applied to a test case, consisting of a dummy integral bladed disk made of Ns = 48 identical sectors, shown in Figure 5, modeled applying the cyclic symmetry boundary conditions. Forced response calculations are performed around the resonances of the first modal family, corresponding to the blade in-plane bending mode. Figure 5.
Dummy blisk (left) and contact elements between the damper and the blade platforms: full view (up) and zoom (down).

The disk sector is modeled with Ansys® release 11 by means of SOLID95 brick element, mapped meshing is used and the total number of nodes is 2052. The dummy UPD has the same mesh features for a total of 1407 nodes.
Wedge shaped UPDs, located under the blade platforms, have damper angles αL = αR = 45° and nominal mass mnom = 0.0044 kg.
The centrifugal force of the damper is modeled as a distributed load, projected on the modal basis of the damper according to equation (25).

Contact stiffness over each damper side has been estimated by assuming a flat punch contact (Allara, 2009) and dividing uniformly the total contact stiffness over each contact pair. Contact elements are placed over the blade/damper contact surfaces as shown in Figure 5, neglecting the contribution of the axial relative displacements. The coefficient of friction is set equal to μ = 0.5, in accordance with experimental results available in the literature (Filippi et al., 2004) referring to typical materials used for bladed disks of aero-engines.

sec.title: 6.2. Results
sec.p: The coupled methodology is implemented in a numerical solver to calculate the forced response of the blisk for different values of damper mass m, different levels of excitation and different engine orders n*.

In Figure 6, the FRF curves for n* = 12 are shown for different values of the damper mass m as reported in the figure. The typical trend of the stick/slip nonlinear phenomenon is clearly visible: as the mass of the damper is gradually increased (by changing the damper density), the frequency of the response peak shifts to values higher than the resonant frequency of the free response (i.e. without damper) to finally reach the fully- stuck response. This effect is due to the increase of the contact normal loads at the damper/platform contacts, producing a gradual increase of the number of contact pairs in full-stick conditions, and consequently an increase of the contact stiffness. At the same time the trend of the peak response shows a minimum corresponding to the maximum friction damping generated at the contacts. Figure 6.
Frequency response functions for different damper masses, n* = 12. The factor referring to each curve is a multiplier of the nominal mass.

A jump phenomenon is clearly visible in some of the FRF curves, caused by a softening effect due to partial lift off of the contacts during vibration, as described in Yang et al. (1998); the use of the pseudo-arc length continuation method to solve the nonlinear balance equations of the system allows computing both the stable and the unstable branches of the resulting FRF curves.

In Figure 7, the vibration amplitude of the blade tip is plotted for different levels of external excitation. In the case of low excitation level, the damper is fully stuck with the blades, but as the excitation becomes larger a softening effect is clearly visible and the response curve tends towards the linear curve of the bladed disk without UPDs. Figure 7.
Response curves for different level of excitation, n* = 12.

One of the most important effects of the coupled methodology described in this paper is the capability to take into account the effect of the contact status on the distribution of static normal loads acting on the contacts.

Consider now the FRF curve of Figure 6, with m = 5 mnom and focus the attention at frequency 509.5 Hz, included in the frequency range where the jump phenomenon occurs; two stable solutions are available at the lower and at the upper branches of the curve, as shown in Figure 8(a). Both the distribution and the total value of the static normal loads at the left side for the two stable solutions (Figure 8(b) and (c) differ from each other, even if the value of the centrifugal force is the same). This kind of behavior proves that the contact status affects the distribution of static normal loads and that a coupled methodology is necessary to take into account this phenomenon. Figure 8.
(a) Frequency response functions zoom for m = 5mnom, n* = 12. (b) Upper branch: Static normal load distribution (total normal load = 311 N). (c) Lower branch: Static normal load distribution (total normal load = 328 N).

Furthermore, consider the set of response curves of Figure 7 which correspond to different values of external excitation; select the frequency of 538 Hz, corresponding to the resonance frequency in full-stick conditions, and plot the distribution of static normal loads corresponding to different excitation levels, as shown in Figure 9. In all the plots the value of the centrifugal force is the same, because they refer to the same damper mass and to the same excitation frequency (i.e. the same rotation speed) but the distribution of static normal loads and the total static normal load (see Table 1) change case-by-case, proving again that the contact status affects both the distribution of the static normal loads and the total static normal load keeping the bodies in contact. Figure 9.
Static normal loads @ 538 Hz (n* = 12) for different levels of excitation.
Table 1.
Total values of static normal loads of cases shown in Figure 9
External force (% of nominal force) 1% 2% 10% 20% 100% 500%
Total static normal load (N) 47.5 51.5 66.5 70.9 72.9 68.1

A third proof is finally provided. The dynamics of the bladed disk is analyzed for two different conditions:
engine order n* = 12 and damper mass m = 2.5 mnom
engine order n* = 24 and damper mass m = 10 mnom.

The same frequency range is used for both the analyses and the forced response of the blade tip in the circumferential direction is computed and plotted in Figure 10. At an angular frequency ω, in the two cases the value of the centrifugal force acting on the damper is the same: (29)1.FC=m·Ω2·r=2.5·mnom·(ωeo)2·r=2.5144·ω2·r2.FC=m·Ω2·r=10·mnom·(ωeo)2·r=10576·ω2·r=2.5144·ω2·r, but the total value and the distributions of static normal loads, shown in Figure 10, are not the same, proving that the contact kinematics of the blade platforms, which depends on inter-blade phase angle, affects the total value and the distribution of static normal loads and confirming that in order to capture this feature a coupled approach is necessary. In detail, the differences between the static normal load distributions are almost negligible at 440 Hz, where a large part of the contact area is in stick conditions, but becomes relevant at 520 Hz where stick-slip phenomena and partial lift-off occurs. Figure 10.
Forced response @ different engine orders and damper masses. Total values and distributions of static normal loads (N) over the left contact nodes.

In order to check the consistency of the method, the evolution of the contact maps at resonance for different values of damper mass (m = 25 mnom, 50 mnom, 100 mnom and 200 mnom) are plotted in Figure 11 by means of three colours corresponding to three possible contact status of the contact model described in Section 3:
– white: full-stick,
– grey: alternating stick-slip,
– black: alternating stick-slip-lift off
Figure 11.
Contact maps at resonance on the left damper side.

Results are consistent with the physical problem, since for the largest value of the damper mass the most part of the contact is in stick conditions but as the damper mass decreases the portion of contact area where slip occurs becomes larger and significant lift-off occurs, mostly at the upper part of the contact area, where larger normal relative displacements are expected in case of in-plane bending motion of the blades.

Furthermore, looking at Table 2, where the total values of the static normal loads, that acts on the left side, are plotted, it is clear that the relationship between the damper mass (i.e. the centrifugal force) and the static normal load is nonlinear; as the damper mass becomes two times larger, the increase in the total static normal load is lower. Table 2.
Total values of static normal loads of cases shown in Figure 11
Damper mass (x nominal mass) 25 50 100 200
Total static normal load (N) 1800 3560 6780 12150

A second check of the consistency of the method is also proposed, using as a reference the static solution of a rigid symmetric wedge pressed between two rigid inclined walls (Figure 12), for which, it is well known in the literature (Sinclair and Cormier, 2002), the following relationship holds between the total static tangential force T and the total static normal force N (30)T=μ·N if tan(α) > μ. Figure 12.
A symmetric wedge pressed between two inclined walls.

The full-stick response curve shown in Figure 13 (left) is used. In detail, the total static tangential force and the total static normal force are computed for several points of the curve, characterized by decreasing amplitudes, and the ratio T/μN is plotted versus the vibration amplitude Figure 13 - right). As expected, as the vibration amplitude decreases, the plotted ratio tends towards the unity value, consistently with the expected static solution of equation (30). Figure 13.
Full-stick response curve (left) and static T/μN ratio vs vibration amplitude (right).

Due to the nonlinearity of friction, the calculation of exact distributions of static normal loads at step 1 requires that static analysis is performed for each value of the centrifugal force. This is an unfeasible procedure due to the large calculation time, and, as a consequence, some kind of approximation is necessary. In this case, the following procedure is adopted:
the static normal load distributions, corresponding to a damper mass m* = 10 x mnom at a frequency f * = 450 Hz, are calculated a priori through a preliminary nonlinear static analysis. The finite element commercial software used to calculate the static load distribution is ANSYS® and the contact element is the CONTAC52 which represents two surfaces which may maintain or break physical contact and may slide relative to each other. Tangential and normal contact stiffness and friction coefficient are the input parameters. The solution is calculated with the penalty method provided by ANSYS® solution algorithms library.
The static normal loads computed at step 1 are then used to compute the forced response of the system in the frequency range shown in Figure 6 for several damper masses, using the dynamic balance equations (27) of the bladed disk and of the damper (23) and the original contact element described in Yang et al. (1998). In order to scale the distribution of static normal loads computed at step 1, the following assumptions are made
○ the static normal loads are proportional to the damper mass
○ the static normal loads are proportional to the squared rotation speed.

The response curves are plotted in Figure 14, where the full lines represent the forced response calculated with the coupled methodology and the dashed lines the calculation performed with the uncoupled approach. Large differences are observed for small values of the damper mass, where, according to the past technical literature about UPDs, the system is not robust since small variations of the centrifugal force (i.e. of static normal loads) may introduce a large variation of the response amplitude. Figure 14.
Comparison of frequency response function curves computed with the coupled (full) and the uncoupled methods.

Furthermore, if we observe the trend of the curves for values of the damper mass larger than the optimum one, higher amplitudes are predicted using the coupled approach. This feature is consistent with the results shown in Figure 13: when the system oscillates, the static tangential forces are lower than those predicted in static conditions and therefore the static normal loads are larger. As a result the system is closer to the full-stick condition, as correctly predicted in Figure 14.

It is also observed that the frequency shift predicted by the two methods is similar but the uncoupled methodology leads to a small underestimation of this phenomenon. Also this feature can be fully justified. According to the preliminary nonlinear static analysis performed at step 1 of the uncoupled approach, the detachment of the upper row of contact nodes is predicted by ANSYS®. This initial gap is not recovered during step 2. As a result, even in full-stick conditions the total contact stiffness is lower than that predicted by the coupled approach.

sec.title: 7. Conclusion
sec.p: In this paper, a methodology for the forced response calculation of bladed disks with wedge dampers is described. It is based on the coupling of the static and of the dynamic balance equations of the system. With the proposed method the two-step approach, currently representing the state of the art, can be replaced by a single-step approach, without any need for a preliminary nonlinear static analysis to compute the static pre-loads acting on the contact areas.

By means of the proposed method, the distribution of static normal loads, which largely influence the amount of energy dissipated at the contacts, can be properly predicted, taking into account the effect of the contact status during vibration.

In order to prove the relevance of the problem and the effectiveness of the method, a numerical test case is proposed: a dummy bladed disk with wedge dampers under cyclic symmetry boundary conditions. Due to the conforming contact, the wedge damper represents the most suitable case to stress how the coupled methodology allows taking into account the effect of the contact status on the static contact force distribution.

Both the disk and the damper have been modeled by FEM in order to describe a general approach which can be applied to different damper configurations. In order to characterize the local contact status, all the nodes lying at the contact surface (around 100) have been used as contact nodes in the analysis, but at the same time to preserve reasonable computation times a modal reduction is also applied.
On the basis of the above mentioned remarks, it is concluded that the proposed method is an effective tool for a more accurate simulation of the forced response of bladed disks with UPDs.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work was supported by the Italian Ministry of University and Research [grant number PRIN 2006].

def.p: bladed disk stiffness, damping, mass matrices
